title: Quiz 3: HIV/AIDS Basics & Transmission
topicName: Unit Six: STIs and HIV AIDS
description: Test your knowledge on the fundamental biology of HIV, how it is transmitted, and how it is NOT transmitted.

questions.question: HIV stands for ___BLANK___ ___BLANK___ Virus.
questions.hint: It affects Humans and causes Immune deficiency.

questions.question: HIV belongs to which group of viruses?
questions.explanation: HIV is a retrovirus, which uses reverse transcriptase to convert its RNA into DNA within the host cell.

questions.question: Which of the following specific defence cells does HIV bind to and destroy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: HIV targets CD4 lymphocytes (also known as T-helper cells).
questions.hint: Think about the immune system cells.

questions.question: Classify the following activities as 'High Risk' or 'No Risk' for HIV transmission:
questions.explanation: HIV is transmitted via blood/fluids (needles, sex) but not casual contact or vectors (mosquitoes).
questions.hint: Does the activity involve exchange of infected body fluids?

questions.question: Which enzyme allows the HIV virus to take over a cell's genetic equipment?
questions.explanation: Reverse Transcriptase converts viral RNA into DNA, allowing it to integrate into the host.

questions.question: Which body fluids are the most likely modes of HIV transmission? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: HIV is found in infectious quantities in blood, semen, vaginal secretions, and breast milk. Not sweat.
questions.hint: Think of fluids exchanged during sex, birth, or breastfeeding.

questions.question: What is the term for infections that take advantage of a weakened immune system to flourish in people with HIV?
questions.explanation: Opportunistic infections take the 'opportunity' of low immunity to attack.

questions.question: The presence of other STIs, such as syphilis or chancroids, increases the risk of HIV transmission.
questions.explanation: True. Ulcerations allow the virus to enter the body more easily during sex.
questions.hint: Think about open sores and barriers.

questions.question: According to the study material, which HIV type is noted as the 'commonest' affecting humans?

richContent.content: Note: While global statistics vary, answer based strictly on the provided text.

questions.explanation: The text explicitly states: 'Those that affect humans, are HIV1 and HIV2, the commonest being HIV2.'
questions.hint: Check the specific sentence in the 'Cause of HIV/AIDS' section.

questions.question: Why is HIV/AIDS considered a 'syndrome'?

options.text: Because it presents with a collection of signs and symptoms resulting from lowered immunity
Because it only affects the blood
Because it has a quick cure

questions.explanation: It is a syndrome because it manifests as a collection of various symptoms and infections due to immune deficiency.
